de.ovgu.featureide.fm.core.base

Interface IConstraint

  • All Superinterfaces:
    IEventManager, IFeatureModelElement
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AConstraint, Constraint, ExtendedConstraint

    public interface IConstraint
extends IFeatureModelElement
    The IConstraint interface represents any class which acts in the sense of a Constraint in FeatureIDE.

    A constraint is a propositional formula on features inside a feature model which gives further conditions a valid configuration must satisfy. A constraint allows conditions statements which are not directly expressibly using the FeatureDiagramEditor since feature models are typically modeled in a hierarchy here.

    A constraint can affect a set of features depending on the conditions given by both the feature model and other constraints. For instance, a constraint can lead to a condition on features which is constant (un-)satisfied, or forces an optional group of features to be mandatory. These affects can be analyzed such that it is known whenever a given constraint result in such effects (see ConstraintAttribute).

    For ease of use, FeatureIDE provides an adapter for this interface, AConstraint which can be used as a starting point for custom implementations. In a broader sense, constraints in FeatureIDE also satisfy the IFeatureModelElement element which deals with identification of constraints and models.

    Instances of IConstraint are intended to be instantiated by a IFeatureModelFactory.

    Example
    The following example shows the instantiation of a IConstraint instance using FeatureIDE's default FeatureModel and Constraint implementation over the standard factories. The constraint created give the condition, that a feature A implies another feature B. IFeatureModel model = FMFactoryManager.getFactory().createFeatureModel(); IConstraint c = FMFactoryManager.getFactory().createConstraint(model, new Implies(new Literal("A"), new Literal("B")));
    Since:
    3.0
    Author:
    Sebastian Krieter, Marcus Pinnecke, Marlen Bernier, Dawid Szczepanski
    See Also:
    Default implementation of IConstraint (as starting point for custom implementations), Interface for feature constraints (IFeature), Interface for feature models (IFeatureModel), Interface for feature properties (IFeatureProperty), Interface for a feature's structure (IFeatureStructure), Feature model element default implementation (IFeatureModelElement implementation), Default implementation for features (AFeature), Default implementation for feature models (FeatureModel), Default implementation for feature properties (FeatureProperty), Default implementation for a feature's structure (FeatureStructure)

    • Method Detail

      • clone

        IConstraint clone(IFeatureModel newFeatureModel)
        Constructs a new instance of IConstraint equal to this constraint but with a new reference.

        A new constraint equal to this is created. Optional, the feature model can be changed. More in detail a new constraint c' is constructed based on this constraint c such that at least
        • c underlying node n containing the propositional formula is accessible by c'. A deep copy of n is not required.
        • the flag indicating a selection of this constraint in the UI (e.g., FeatureDiagramEditor) is equal for c and c'
        • if c inherits IFeatureModelElement, c' must deep copy the required members of this implementation
        It holds c' != c and c.equals(c').

        Note: the parameter newFeatureModel is intended to change the feature model context of the newly created, and affects members if this constraint implements IFeatureModelElement.

        Notes on side effects and null references
        Calling this method:
        • does not affect the members in this object.
        • does not affect the parameter newFeatureModel.
        • the parameter newFeature is expected to be non-null
        • the returned result is guaranteed non-null and modifiable
        Parameters:
        newFeatureModel - a possible new context for this constraint
        Returns:
        a new instance of this constraint which has a new reference
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        Default implementation for constraints (extending implementation for IFeatureModelElement, Feature model element interface

      • getConstraintAttribute

        ConstraintAttribute getConstraintAttribute()
        Returns analysis results for this constraint, i.e., how this constraint affects the feature model.

        A constraint can affect a set of features depending on the conditions given by both the feature model and other constraints. For instance, a constraint can lead to a condition on features which is constant (un-)satisfied, or forces an optional group of features to be mandatory. These affects can be analyzed such that it is known whenever a given constraint result in such effects (see ConstraintAttribute).

        The result of a former analysis is intended to be stored in the constraint, such that this methods returns the affects of this constraint to the model. Possible affects by this constraint are:
        • leads to dead features
        • leads to false optional features
        • do not affect the model in a special way
        • is redundant, i.e., the condition by this constraint is already covered elsewhere
        • leads to a tautology expression
        • leads to unsatisfiable expressions
        • voids the feature model


        Notes on side effects and null references
        Calling this method:
        • does not affect the members in this object.
        • the returned result is guaranteed non-null and modifiable
        Returns:
        A value which indicates how the constraints affects the feature model
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        constraint attributes

      • getContainedFeatures

        java.util.Collection<IFeature> getContainedFeatures()
        Returns the collection of features contained in the underlying formula of this constraint.

        A constraint contains one or more features. In the default implementation, the propositional formula is constructed via nodes of a satisfiability solver (see Node). This method returns a view on these items.

        Note: The returned collection is intended to be cached. If the cache is empty, setContainedFeatures() is called automatically. The return collection might be out-dated until a new call to setContainedFeatures() is done manually.

        Notes on side effects and null references
        Calling this method:
        • does affects the members in this object.
        • the returned result is guaranteed non-null and modifiable
        Returns:
        a collections of features which are part of the propositional formula of this constraint
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        setContainedFeatures()

      • getDeadFeatures

        java.util.Collection<IFeature> getDeadFeatures()
        Returns the parameter of the last setDeadFeatures(Iterable) call, or null if no such call happens before invoking this method.

        Note: The dead feature collection is not calculated when calling this method. Therefore, a call to setDeadFeatures(Iterable) is required plus eventually a call to getDeadFeatures(SatSolver, IFeatureModel, Collection).

        Notes on side effects and null references
        Calling this method:
        • does not affect the members in this object.
        • the returned result is guaranteed non-null and unmodifiable
        Returns:
        A collection of features which are marked as dead features.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        setDeadFeatures(Iterable), getDeadFeatures(SatSolver, IFeatureModel, Collection)

      • getDeadFeatures

        java.util.Collection<IFeature> getDeadFeatures(SatSolver solver,
                                               IFeatureModel featureModel,
                                               java.util.Collection<IFeature> exlcudeFeatuers)
        Calculates and returns a iterable collection of features which are marked as dead due to the affect of this constraint to the feature model featureModel. The calculation whenever a constraint leads to dead features is done over the instance of a satisfaction solver given by the parameter solver. From the calculated set of dead features in featureModel, the features contained in excludeFeatures are excluded before the collection of dead features is return, i.e., features in excludeFeatures are not contained in the resulting collection even if they might be dead.

        Node on duplicate elements: The calculated collection of dead features have not to contain duplicates.

        Notes on side effects and null references
        Calling this method:
        • does not affect the members in this object.
        • might affect cache entries in the parameter newFeatureModel.
        • does not affect the parameter execludeFeatures.
        • the parameter are assumed to be non-null
        • the returned result is guaranteed non-null and modifiable
        Parameters:
        solver - a satisfaction solver
        featureModel - the feature model for which the affect of this constraint should be analyzed in terms of dead feature affect.
        exlcudeFeatuers - a collection features which should be removed from the resulting collection of dead features before this collection is returned.
        Returns:
        An iterable over dead features in featureModel caused by this constraint, which are not included in the excludeFeatures collection.
        Since:
        3.0

      • getFalseOptional

        java.util.Collection<IFeature> getFalseOptional()
        Returns the parameter of the last setFalseOptionalFeatures(IFeatureModel, Collection) call, or null if no such call happens before invoking this method.

        Note: The false optional feature collection is not calculated when calling this method. Therefore, a call to setFalseOptionalFeatures(IFeatureModel, Collection) is required.

        Notes on side effects and null references
        Calling this method:
        • does not affect the members in this object.
        • the returned result is guaranteed non-null and modifiable
        Returns:
        A collection of features which are marked as dead features.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        setDeadFeatures(Iterable), getDeadFeatures(SatSolver, IFeatureModel, Collection)

      • hasHiddenFeatures

        boolean hasHiddenFeatures()
        Returns whenever this constraints contains features which are marked as hidden

        Checks if one or more features contained in this feature is marked as hidden by checking if one feature in the set of contained features is hidden or, if the parent of one feature in the set of contained features is hidden. If such a feature is found, the method returns true, otherwise false.

        Notes on side effects and null references
        Calling this method:
        • does not affect the members in this object.
        Returns:
        true if a feature (or a features parent) is marked as hidden and contained in the formula of this constraint
        Since:
        3.0

      • setConstraintAttribute

        void setConstraintAttribute(ConstraintAttribute attribute,
                            boolean notifyListeners)
        Sets the analysis attribute for this constraints which determine how this constraint affects features.

        A constraint can affect a set of features depending on the conditions given by both the feature model and other constraints. For instance, a constraint can lead to a condition on features which is constant (un-)satisfied, or forces an optional group of features to be mandatory. These affects can be analyzed such that it is known whenever a given constraint result in such effects (see ConstraintAttribute).



        Notes on side effects and null references
        Calling this method:
        • does affect the members in this object.
        • does not affect the parameters.
        • the parameters are expected to be non-null
        Parameters:
        attribute - The affect caused by this constraint
        notifyListeners - A flag indicating if listeners should be notified about this change
        Since:
        3.0

      • setDeadFeatures

        Notes on side effects and null references
        Calling this method:
        • does affect the members in this object.
        • does not affect the parameter deadFeatures.
        • the parameter deadFeatures is expected to be non-null
        Parameters:
        deadFeatures - iterable of features which are claimed to be dead
        See Also:
        getDeadFeatures(), Setting an empty iterable

      • setFalseOptionalFeatures

        boolean setFalseOptionalFeatures(IFeatureModel featureModel,
                                 java.util.Collection<IFeature> collection)
        Calculates and sets the collections of false optional features in featureModel caused by this constraint.

        The set of false optional features is updated to the current state, and accessible by calling getFalseOptional(). The method returns true if this set is empty, and false otherwise.

        Note: The collection collection is modified such that newly calculated false optional features are removed from collection (if any). Therefore, getFalseOptional() returns the entire set of false optional features while collection contains elements (as provided before calling this method) minus the content of getFalseOptional().

        Notes on side effects and null references
        Calling this method:
        • does affect the members in this object.
        • does affect the parameter collection.
        • the parameters are expected to be non-null
        Parameters:
        featureModel - The context which is affected by this constraint
        collection - A set containing features. Elements in collection are removed, if they are marked as false optional during this method call.
        Returns:
        true if this constraint affects a least one feature to be false optional, false otherwise.
        Since:
        3.0
